1_introduction.title: 1. Introduction
1_introduction.prompt: Introduce the {system_name} as the 'Item' defined under ISO 26262-3:2018. Clearly articulate its primary function within the vehicle system architecture and its significance from a functional safety perspective. Explain the critical role this Item Definition plays as the foundational document for subsequent Hazard Analysis and Risk Assessment (HARA) and the development of the Functional Safety Concept, ensuring alignment among all relevant stakeholders.

2_1_legal_requirements.title: 2.1 Legal Requirements, National and International Standards
2_1_legal_requirements.prompt: Provide a comprehensive overview of the legal regulations, national standards, and international standards applicable to the design, development, testing, and safety validation of the {system_name}. Detail how standards such as UNECE R100, ISO 6469, ISO 26262, and IEC 61508 specifically govern its functional safety requirements.

2_2_functional_behaviour.title: 2.2 Functional Behaviour at Vehicle Level
2_2_functional_behaviour.prompt: Describe the functional behavior of the {system_name} across various vehicle operational contexts. Detail its expected performance during distinct operating modes, including but not limited to Standby, Pre-Charge, Driving, Charging, Thermal Management, Fault, and Sleep modes. Explain the primary functions executed and the item's state within each mode.

2_3_performance_requirements.title: 2.3 Required Quality, Performance, and Availability
2_3_performance_requirements.prompt: Specify the critical non-functional performance requirements for the {system_name} that are directly relevant to functional safety. This includes defining quantitative targets for accuracy (e.g., sensor measurement precision), response time (e.g., fault detection and reaction delays), reliability (e.g., Mean Time Between Failures - MTBF), and availability (e.g., system uptime percentage). Explain the safety implications if these targets are not met.

2_4_constraints.title: 2.4 Constraints Regarding the Item
2_4_constraints.prompt: Outline the environmental constraints (e.g., operating temperature ranges, humidity, vibration levels), functional dependencies (e.g., reliance on specific sensor signals, CAN bus integrity, 12V power supply), and resource constraints (e.g., maximum power consumption, computational capacity) applicable to the {system_name}. Clearly state the assumptions made regarding these constraints for the item to function safely and effectively.

2_5_consequences_of_shortfalls.title: 2.5 Potential Consequences of Behavioural Shortfalls
2_5_consequences_of_shortfalls.prompt: Analyze and describe the potential hazardous events and their consequences resulting from the failure or incorrect behavior of the {system_name}. Detail the potential impact on vehicle safety, occupants, and other road users. This analysis is crucial for input into the Hazard Analysis and Risk Assessment (HARA) to determine ASIL ratings.

2_6_actuator_capabilities.title: 2.6 Capabilities of the Actuators (or Assumed Capabilities)
2_6_actuator_capabilities.prompt: Detail the specific capabilities of the {system_name} to execute safety-related actions. Specify the speed and effectiveness of safety responses, such as the maximum time allowed for contactor opening in a fault condition (e.g., within 30 milliseconds) or the activation time for a cooling request (e.g., within 500 milliseconds). These values are essential for HARA analysis, particularly for determining Severity and Controllability.

3_boundary_and_interfaces.title: 3. Boundary of the Item, Interfaces, and Interaction Assumptions

3_1_elements_of_item.title: 3.1 Elements of the Item
3_1_elements_of_item.prompt: Define the physical and logical boundaries of the {system_name} by listing all included hardware components (e.g., Electronic Control Unit, sensors, actuators) and software modules. Explicitly state which components, subsystems, or functions are considered outside the scope of this item definition.

3_2_assumptions_on_vehicle_effects.title: 3.2 Assumptions Concerning Effects on the Vehicle
3_2_assumptions_on_vehicle_effects.prompt: Describe the assumed effects of the {system_name}'s behavior on the overall vehicle dynamics and the driver. This includes assumptions such as the driver's expected response to warnings issued by the item, the vehicle's ability to safely transition to a defined safe state if required by the item, and the expected interaction with other vehicle systems during fault conditions.

3_3_functionality_required_by_others.title: 3.3 Functionality Required by Other Items
3_3_functionality_required_by_others.prompt: Describe the specific functionalities and information provided by the {system_name} that are required by other systems within the vehicle. For example, the Vehicle Control Unit (VCU) may require the State of Charge (SoC) or available power limits from the Battery Management System (BMS), or the charging system may require permission signals.

3_4_dependencies_on_other_items.title: 3.4 Functionality of Other Items Required by This Item
3_4_dependencies_on_other_items.prompt: Detail the functionalities and data inputs that the {system_name} requires from other systems to operate correctly and safely. This includes mode status information from the VCU, raw sensor data (current, voltage, temperature), communication network availability (e.g., CAN bus), and stable power supply.

3_5_function_allocation.title: 3.5 Allocation and Distribution of Functions
3_5_function_allocation.prompt: Explain how the safety-critical functions associated with the {system_name} are allocated and distributed across different hardware and software components, potentially involving interactions with other vehicle systems. For instance, clarify whether State of Charge estimation is performed solely by the BMS software or involves other systems, or how thermal control actions are coordinated between the BMS and the dedicated cooling system controller.

3_6_operational_scenarios.title: 3.6 Operational Scenarios Impacting Functionality
3_6_operational_scenarios.prompt: Describe specific operational scenarios that significantly impact the functionality and safety considerations of the {system_name}. Examples include fast charging protocols, cold weather start-up procedures, high-speed driving with sustained power demands, collision detection triggering safety protocols, or operation in extreme environmental conditions. This description is vital for developing realistic scenarios for HARA.

4_conclusion.title: 4. Conclusion
4_conclusion.prompt: Confirm that this Item Definition fully satisfies the requirements outlined in ISO 26262-3:2018, Clause 5.4. Summarize the key aspects covered, including the defined scope, interfaces, functional behavior, constraints, and safety considerations. Affirm its readiness to serve as the basis for the subsequent Hazard Analysis and Risk Assessment (HARA) and Functional Safety Concept development phases.

5_approvals.title: 5. Approvals
5_approvals.prompt: Include a placeholder table intended for the signatures and dates of key personnel responsible for approving this Item Definition, such as the Safety Engineer, System Architect, and Project Manager.
